posts.name: Debbie Bernier
posts.cooked:
https://info.firstinspires.org/hubfs/Education_Resources/WorforceDevelopment/ProgramofStudy/Introduction_to_Programming_Course_Outline.pdf

This is a very nice outline of a programming course and clearly it’s from FIRST based on the URL. However I can’t find where the course lives.

Does anyone know?

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked:
It is linked to from Career and Technical Education | FIRST . It appears to be an example syllabus:

In the remainder of this guide, you will find resources to develop your own program of study with example courses that teachers, students, and schools can use to implement FIRST into their school or independent learning program. We currently have example syllabi to support the following levels of courses which can be implemented across three different career clusters.

posts.name: Debbie Bernier
posts.cooked: Thanks. That’s unfortunate.  But I appreciate that you found where it came from.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
crazycats:

This is a very nice outline of a programming course

I’m not really sure I agree.

image 1910×1012 165 KB

image 1910×1012 165 KB

image 1910×1012 165 KB

How are students supposed to learn inheritance before how they learn how to use objects and methods?  Much less, before they know how to use conditionals?

This is bizarre.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Regardless of the sequencing, it is nice to see the linked course descriptions. I know some states have FIRST competitions as an official CTSO* for CTE courses, and having some sort of course outlines is helpful.

*Career & Technical Student Organization membership is a requirement of students completing a Career Technical Education pathway

posts.name: Arnav Ranjan
posts.cooked: I’m assuming that methods and objects would be covered in Java Basics under programming robots section (d) briefly, otherwise learning inheritance would be useless, but its weird that that more in depth is done after inheritance.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: The time-based/Command-based introduction that early (and, implicitly, teaching it with an understand of inheritence) seems weird to me - I’d tend to say the teacher picks it up front, teaches the other things as needed, then wraps back around to why the initial choice was made.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I don’t understand the “differentiate between…” goal at all - surely the purpose of the course is to learn how to program a robot, rather than to learn a taxonomy of robot code architectures?

The longer I stare at the curriculum, the worse it gets.
